												Are you bored of staying in one spot for 10 minutes straight, with hordes of zombies rampaging at your front door and with little ammo to spare?You've come to the right place. Kill specimens. They're not really zombies, we just like mutating things and hope for the best. Although, we did create this... abomination, and it's currently pinning us down with a big♥♥♥♥♥chaingun and this large rocket launcher. Oh, he said something for once in clear English, something like "One in the pi-"Still reading this? Want an actual review of this game? You've come to the next right place. Grab your pistol, give drugs to people, get dosh, buy weapons, survive, buy more weapons, experiment, melee things to death, it's got it all. With Killing Floor 2 coming out next year, and this week's update, this game cannot die. A good handful are still playing it daily, and you can even play by yourself.More of a strategy, if you're playing by yourself, any perk can be the best, even Field Medic. "But I'm not healing anyone!" you say. It's cause you gain awesome abilities by running as fast as a berzerker. Oh yeah, berzerking ravaging through fleshpounds with a claymore sword, we got a badass on the field.Now if you were playing with friends, now we need communication. A six player team can be done properly, if people are very good at this game, like a skilled elite of the FBI or something. Still, this game's got what it worth, and multiplayer is unforgetable.10/10

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												If there's one thing I admire, it's a developer supporting their game long after release.  Killing Floor has been updated with content (a lot of it free) so often that Tripwire Interactive is one of my favorite developers.  But enough about them, let's talk about the game.Killing Floor is a mutant (not zombie and you will be stoned if you refer to them as zombies) survival game.  The premise is that an experiment has gone wrong, mutants emerge, blah blah blah, you've heard it before.  We're not here for the story, we're here for the guns and the killing.  Though one interesting bit about the backstory is that originally it was the military and police dealing with the mutants, but now everyone is in on the fun.  You have DJ's wielding katanas, a guy in a chicken suit, santa clause, and even the pyro from Team Fortress 2.The game takes place in the UK, with hilariously over the top stereotypes for each person.  From the accent to the forms of swearing, you'll find yourself spamming in game commands just to hear all the things they can say.You'll find yourself in various locations.  The game does support custom maps, but the maps Tripwire have made themselves are amazing as well.  You'll find in labs, carnivals, and even the ruins Aperture Laboratory.  Some have gimmicks like elevators and what not that will allow you to escape from the mutants.Speaking of mutants, there are tons of mutants.  You have the Clot, your standard peon.  Be aware of it's grab though, it'll root you in place.  The Gorefast is an upgraded version that can run, but also possesses a longer attack range.  The Stalker can turn invisible and the Crawler jumps around.  Both are easy to kill though.  There are your fat zombies, Bloats, who not only puke on you, but will also explode in a shower of puke when you shoot them too much in the torso.  You have Sirens, mutants in straight jackets that will scream, disabling your grenades and doing pure health damage.  Husks will prevent you from camping by shooting fireballs at you.  Now for the big ones, for which you will need big guns.  The Scrake has a chain saw, get him to half health and he'll charge you.  Same with the Fleshpound, but more frightening.  With two spiked gloves, he'll become enraged and chase you.  At the end of every game, you'll face a Patriarch, armed with a chain saw and rocket launcher to cover the distance.  Get to close and he'll smack you.  Do too much damage and he'll run, turn invisible and heal.  So how do you kill him?  Keep pounding him with all you got and don't give him time to rest.Of course, to help you kill all these things is a vast arsenal.  You have assault rifles, shotguns (pump, semi, and fully auto), handguns, smg's, snipers, explosives, and even make-shift weapons.  Supporting you are also perks.  Like to blow stuff up?  Equip the demolition perk.  Shotguns are your thing?  Equip the Support Specialist perk.  There's a perk for everyone.TL:DR - Horde style survival game, played best with friends (up to 6 people, more can be supported with mods).  May get repetitive, but if that's the case, maybe you should try a map other than West London.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												You kill zeds (zombies) for gore, perks and weapons. The more gruesome are the kills, the more money you get. Money means weapons, ammo and armor. So, this game rewards you for brutality. Which is kind of cool thing for a shooter. Cooperation, correct weapon choice and reaction speed are critical to succeed at this game, more than in any other. I think, after KF, you will be better at any shooter.KF also supports Steam Workshop content. And there are DLC characters, you can either buy or unlock by achievements.The downsides are a rather complicated interface, slow perk progress and outdated graphics quality.Nevertheless, the game offers a decent amount of fun for some time, especially when played with friends. It starts to feel repetitive after you have played all the maps and modes, which aren't that many actually. A content for 3-7 evenings, perhaps, until you've tried everything the base game has to offers. Don't see much point of buying DLCs, though, which basically are pretty guns and pretty characters.I recommend to get KF on sales. 5 € well spent. KF is one of those games you return to from time to time.My overall rating: 7/10.

Posted: July 20, 2016
												This game is a once in a while game. As person, who netted around 1500 hours in this (I had an account hijacked). I am essentially a vet of this game, I joined in October of 2013, I played around in single player, being afraid of fleshpounds and the patriarch I seldom played it. Eventually after watching SSoHPKC play this game it inspired me to play it a lot more. I was 14 turning 15 and this game was my birthday money well spent. It's amazing, its fun, the music is brutal and grindy as are the steampunk(esk) graphics. IF however, you have not bought this game, two things, What in gods name are you waiting for and, please unless youre a left and remapped your controlls, its 'Q' to heal your self, 5 and click to heal others, Caps lock to voice chat and Right Click to aim down sights; and as a personal favor to yourself so you don't seem like some greifing piece of dung, please do NOT play HARD, SUICIDAL OR HELL ON EARTH AS A LEVEL 2!Please don't do those things and play it at your own pace. I love newbies that are fun and tenacious but no one on earth likes the scrub that shoots the Fleshpound on HOE as a level 2 medic and dies and complains that it's everyone elses fault, its not only annoying but very unsportsman-like, with all that said, this is a masterpieces baby <3.With love,The guy who changes his name every weekRabbit

Posted: November 15, 2013
												Overall: 9,75/10 TL;DR: Tossed Dosh at Fleshpound. It became so happy, that it became mad and wanted to hug me rapidly and shredded all zombies along it's path. :Dosh:/10 ! TL;DR #2: Wayne Rooney is smarter than you!My GRANNIE shoots better than you!You prat!Smeghead!You muppet!You gormless tosser!Need to borrow my specs mate?!Who do you think you are, bleeding action man?!And just in case you don't own Killing Floor yet  Oh get on with it, PLOD!PROS:- Teamwork, Teamwork, Teamwork!- Different funny Perks giving advantages to play and master with. - Funny season-specials!- Unreal Engine is good!- (English) Funny phrases for playable character- Upcoming updates/patches are fixing problems and bugs, also new maps and stuff.- Love the sound/music design! GJ Zynthetic!CONS:- Pay2Win weapon DLCs!- Leveling the Perks requires mass play time and mass tasks! Boooring! The more when leveling up your friend/partner. (This can be avoided by testmaps, which will just level up the player without gaining any real skill)- May become boring depending on the customer if not the objective mode came up with the update.- It's enough to have ONE "player" to join and screw things to ruin the entire gameplay on Suicidal/Hell on Earth Difficulty. No-one can predict this before it is actualy happening in the present.DOSH! Also take note, if you like such games about zombie apocalypse, (co-op) survival horror or a mix of both (Ex. Left 4 Dead (2), Resident Evil (3,4,5,6), Contagion...) this is your next game to play. Oh yeah, they differ a lot from COD BO Zombies. Frankly, in Killing Floor these creatures are NOT zombies (they are specimen) but still considered as zombies.Title is a little confusing. Killing Floor... You don't walk up to somewhere and get killed by a trap laid on the floor or below nor you don't kill somebody by laying or triggering traps on the floor (except mines). The floor doesn't kill anything neither get's the floor killed. Still good game!... Filling Kloor a'ight!

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												A little gem for some mindless killing fun or either a challenging horde fighting game to do with some friends or strangers, or simply by yourself, with the goal to survive many waves of monsters, until you and your teammates are the only living thing left in the map, with each wave getting tougher as more of these monsters will appear, together with stronger and nastier kind of them appearing as you progress in the game.The player will be given a character provided with the basic pistol and basic melee weapon in the game, and as soon the game starts you will be able to use these weak weapons to kill the first handful of monsters. As soon as you've done with this first wave, you will be given the way to go to the Trader, which will sell you many more and way stronger weapons that you can use, instead of your standard cookies and milk. Based on what "Perk" are you going to use, which is the skill level with a certain category of weapons that you can decide to specialize into, such as being better at using shotguns, assault rifles, or being better at healing or at using melee weapons, you will be given a wide variety of weapons that you should be supposed to use, but you can anytime change the kind of weapons you want to use, or completely change the Perk you're playing with. Each of these Perks will also give you a particular role in the game that you will easily find out just by playing it, which is also the way to improve said skills.There are a total of 9 kind of monsters you can encounter during a full game, each with many skills and characteristics meant to pose the players a certain kind of threat based on how dangerous these enemies are, with one last final one that is meant to be the "boss" of the game, the stronger of them all and your final goal to beat the game.In a summary this is the game, which can sound pretty simple and easy, but by playing in harder difficulties you will find out that it requires much strategy depending on the perks you and any of your teammates are playing, by the kind of enemies you have around and the situation you're in.It may be a pretty old game and may have lots of DLCs, which are almost all cosmetic characters or weapons while just 2-3 are actually different weapons, but these aren't that great and is usually better to stick with the ones present for everyone in the game.It's as of today a pretty fun game where many people are still playing on the servers, even with the new KF2 out.If you like a decent good old game that has also a workshop for some game modding that adds some variety to the game, and also runs smoothly even on the oldest computers, you've come to the right page.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												Awesome Coop-game, it is still fun even after years of playing it. It used to have a rock-paper-scissor-like approach, whith each class having unique strenghts and weaknesses making the game very teamplay-demanding. Those were the great time of KF, very hard to beat on the highest difficulty level with a lot of knowledge and teamplay required to make it through the map. Unfortunately, the Devs removed the classes`weaknesses and now every perk can kill every zed and team selection doesnt matter anymore. But it stil is a lot of fun to play and there will be still some challenges for newer players but the veterans will need to play on modded servers like ScrN-Hardcore. Every PC-gamer should definitely have this game in his library!

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Welcome to my review of Killing Floor. Now, I could go on and on with some boring review, but why do that when I can just be straight to the point?This here is Killing Floor. This is a game where you, to great surprise, kill things. In fact, you kill a lot of things. To be honest, I hope you like killing things, because that's this game's primary feature!Not entirely 100% positive what the things are? Don't worry, because we aren't either! Before you know it, you too, will be mindlessly firing the portable killing machine of your choice beside others who share your newly obtained urge to fire weapons at mutants without questioning the logic of why you're a military operative sent against mutants with nothing but a Beretta M9, a knife, a welding tool, and a healing injector that magically recharges over time!What do you do? Simple! You kill things. Once you're done killing things, you get weapons from the money you got from killing things so you can kill more things and earn MORE money to get BETTER weapons to kill more things with, until you finally kill enough things to get to the big thing called the patriarch. By then, hopefully your squad of originally highly unprepared, lighthearted, talkative british soldiers will have killed enough things to get powerful enough weapons to stand a chance against this final mutant! What happens when you win, you ask? You do it all over again! Astonishing, correct?How do you get weapons? Like any fully-unprepared squad of six brits would in an apocalypse! You trust a completely legitimate travelling mercenary who has no affiliation with the army, that conveniently manages to travel from shop to shop for absolutely no reason since it's all within the same small area, without ever having to fight any of the mutants you're facing! We should also note that she is the only living person in the game aside from your squad, so it's your job to make sure that you clean out these completely decimated areas so the people that don't live anymore can be free!But killing things with portable killing machines is just not enough! The game uses a class system. Now, I could use the actual names, but who needs names to confuse people, when we're already throwing logic out the window?! Lets just use fancy, informative descriptions!Our fabulous classes include:Brits who shoot things with automatic weapons and can see invisible women.Brits who heal people with the same automatic weapons they kill things with, while tanking damage like no one else ever could.Brits who burn things.Brits who blow things up.Brits who blast things with shotguns and carry more than anyone else.Brits who snipe enemies from afar and fail to realize pistols are actually powerful in this game.And lastly, Brits who run really fast and use melee weapons to attack the enemies that are also primarily limited to melee attacks!Should you play long enough to level a class up really far, the queen will smile upon your efforts and no longer send you in with just a Beretta M9 and a knife to fight with on the first wave - instead, she will provide you with a weapon for your class that is significantly more useful! In addition, levelling up causes the goddess of guns to bless your firearms that match your class with improved firepower! No, she doesn't give you new kinds of bullets, or modifications to the guns, they just magically obtain greater potential! It makes perfect sense if you don't think about it, and why would you?! Your thoughts should be focused on killing mutants, you bloody fool!But make no mistake - this is NOT a first person shooter! No, this is in fact a killing simulator. That's right, a killing simulator! You aren't just shooting these mutants, it's up to you whether or not you take limbs off their torsos, blast their heads off, decapitate them, burn them alive, or blast them to little bits! Be creative with how you kill mutants, just don't give them the opportunity to be creative as well!Need more guns? Of course you do! That's why there's three weapon pack DLCs! Don't like DLCs? No problem! Turn to modding, and make Killing Floor's battles into an even bigger massacre than they already are!So what are you waiting for? Throw away your logic, bring your friends, lose your social life, and get to slaughtering mutants over and over, because who needs reasons anyway?!

content:
Posted: November 10, 2011
												(Just a small, positive review)This game is the reason I hopped on Steam almost 4 years ago.A truly unique experience with perfect teamplay elements!It has a round-based system in which the game works, you need to survive each round, kill high priority enemies before taking down the smaller ones. And the harder modes would definitely require you to use tactics - which can be ruined by selfish/inept people though.For each enemy & round you complete, you get money which you can then use at the trader to buy weapons, armor & grenades - they are discounted based on how high your specific class is.At the end of the round you will fight the Patriarch, a boss that can be quite dangerous if the team doesn't coordinate well or doesn't have the right classes to fight/distract it.(Also, I made a lot of Steam friends via this game!)I'd recommend playing Killing Floor before getting Killing Floor 2, since this game was the basis on which Killing Floor 2 was based - which is a great game, in it's own right.Personal score: 7.5/10Best regards,Dukhat

content:
Posted: July 13, 2012
												I find Killing Floor to be a very impressive survival based co-operative shooter, it is very simple and easy to understand and for players to connect with. The gamplay itself is very good with 6 varied classes for players to try with different strengths to allow players to have a well rounded team to tackle the hordes with. I find the visuals to still be good even though the game runs on the now old unreal 2 engine, the animation for things such as reloading is also very smooth and creative and is on par and often better than modern released games like Battlefield and Call of Duty in my opinion. The game is especially fun when played with friends or even a good team that you may meet on various servers, but it can be equally fun to be played solo every once in a while. The game itself also has lots of difficulty setting allowing for new players to take it easy and hardcore veterans to still be challenged. The developers of this game are also very supportive and still release updates adding new content in events such as "Twisted Christmas" and "Summer Sideshow" which is always nice to get continued support especially this long after release. Overall: 80/100

content:
Posted: December 21, 2010
												Killing Floor is an FPS Zombie Killing Game that gives you 6 different perks to choose from. Once you have chosen a perk, you can switch anytime in between waves of the current game or while in the lobby. The game is kind of like Horde from Gears of War or Firefight from Halo 3: ODST in being that you fight against waves of enemies and then against a boss at the end of the last wave. You get to level up each perk to a maximum of 6 levels and with each level, you get really cool benefits. At the end of each wave, you can buy weapons/armor/grenades from this shop that opens up at random locations throughout the map. There's only a certain amount of time to shop and the higher the difficulty, the less time..this means that if you're far away from the shop before it opens...you're screwed! Overall, this is a really fun game, it has excellent gameplay and gore, and it's worth the buy!

content:
Posted: January 19
British Metal Zombie Killers  TL;DR Killing Floor is a Fantastic wave based shooter with challenging gameplay , humorous dialogue and a head banging soundtrack. You and 4 teammates will be pit against the bowels of hell as an array of monsters come to tear your nipples off. Using specialized classes with the weapons you purchase you will help each other to survive by strategic placement or running around like lunatics, that have been given to much sugar.Follow us here Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipPros  Fast pacedGreat Co-op experienceRocking SoundtrackEasy for NewcomersCons Lacking a variety in gameplayNo storyLevels do not change any gameplay---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GameplayIn Killing floor choosing a class sets your playstyle for the match, your either going to be running around and keeping you distance or participating in fisticuffs. The game has very little strategy involved other than find a corner and only kill the last zombie when you’re at the merchant. Even though There are numerous types of monsters and weapons, you’ll find yourself buying the same guns every game, the game sadly can become repetitive in its gameplay. Characters While there are no actual characters with a full-fledged story, the dialogue is delightfully British and witty, with funny quips and spammable taunts. There are roughly 100 character skins to choose from , most are just silly military skins but others are refrences like the tf2 pyro. Art/Graphics Killing floor has that gritty film look and it pulls it off so well , with the dark environments and array of characters and monsters. The small maps usually follow a theme and they all give off a feeling of horror.There are many character models to choose form and variants of the monsters, Yet they all seem to fit nicely in the level themes, Even the Christmas ones are very well made.If you like this join us here to get the latest Reviews:Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group : http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipWhat would you like to see for our next review ? Ask in the comment section!

content:
Posted: October 22, 2012
												One of the FPS games on Steam that I'd seriously recommend. It's fun if you're playing casually on Normal or Hard, but if you want one hell of a challenge, try Suicidal or Hell on Earth difficulty. Game is pretty repetitive, but with 7 classes to choose from it makes the game fun. The more you use specific weapons, the more you'll rack up experience for those corresponding classes. The game is extremely fun to play with friends, and practically everyone on Steam either knows about this game or owns it. I'd highly recommend this game to practically everyone. Also, they have events in the Summer, Halloween, and during Christmas.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												(updated review 12/26/2014 [review made more serious])(updated review 6/15/2016) [thoughts on Killing Floor 2])9/10+7 different perks+a lot of different weapons+Heavily team based+difficulty scaling based on # of players+customizable game difficulty/length+9 different types of zombies+boss at the end of every set of waves+few seconds of slow motion after killing a zombie sometimes+challenging+mod support+you can choose between 4 different types of zombies. Hillbillies, sideshow acts, christmas icons, or the regular zombies. (requires editing of internal file)-repetetive-game is very hard starting off-no updating anymore-quite a bit of DLC-may be a little bit glitchyAt the time of this review being made, Killing floor 2 has been announced, and is basicly going to be a better version of killing floor. I would recommend buying Killing Floor 1 (this game) on sale if possible.Edit: At the time, killing floor 2 isn't a good game. Too many bad design choices have been made to kill things that made the core gameplay what it was. I'm still hoping KF2 will rise to be even better than this game, but that's happening reeeeally slowly. So for now, this is the better game, and I still recomend picking it up.and one last thing. It's always the crawlers

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Killing Floor is an FPS zombie Shooter.  It's generally a multiplayer game but the game let's you play solo by setting up a server where no other players can join, so effectively you get single player OR you can play with friends coop.  The game starts with you facing down the first wave of zombies.  During this wave, you must slowly find your way to the shop keeper so you can upgrade your gear (weapons, items, etc).  The shop keeper is somewhere on the map and there's an arrow in yur HUD pointing in the direction of the next shop.  If you clear a wave then a red trail appears showing you exactly where the shop is.  You can customize for more waves by selecting a longer game.  Each wave is kept track of in your HUD, with zombie and wave count.There are items like guns and ammo available for pick up around the map.  The weapons available at the shop aren't bad but generally, if you've opted for the DLC then you have a bigger choice of weapons to use.  Weapons basically have a cumbersome/weight factor so you can't carry everything you want for each wave of zombies.  There are varrying zombies that do several things so depending on what you're facing might depend on what loadout you choose. When you have zombies firing missile launchers in your direction, you may opt for the body armor.The graphics aren't bad for an old game... but it is an old game so you're dealing with an old graphics engine no matter how much DLC you add to your initial game.  There's several unique zombies and creatures that are pretty creative in their gore factor. Headshots have that slow motion action feel to them adding to the eye candy effect a bit.  There is quite a following of the game and there's even new DLC every so often that include maps and unique character sets with tons of achievements to farm for.  There's plenty of maps and the better you know the map, the better you play.  Incidentally, there's no mini-map so you REALLY have to know the map for longer survival and shop locations.  My only real problem with the game is that you can't run.  If you're used to playing COD or some other FPS where you can just take up a sprint... not here.  The game will let you slow down to a walk though.  I'm assuming for better aim as you're moving and firing at the same time.  I'm a fan of Tripwire games so this is right in there as a classic fave.  It's an old game but I'd still recommend it ON SALE... with the DLC on sale.  You can get multiple DLC packages and the game itself super cheap when there's a sale.  Looking forward to Killing Floor 2 for sure.

												I love zombie / apacolypse survival games. Killing floor is no different. Multiplayer and servers can be tricky to set up, but Killing Floor is worth it. Awesome class / character progression system to fit multiplayer or singleplayer roles. Several different zombie types keep the game interesting. There's also a wide variety of unlockable guns and DLC guns for each class.I'm also a big fan of welding doors shut to temporarily hold off the impending doom. The difficulty levels are great in case the game gets too easy (or hard). I definetly recommend this game if you like survival / apocalypse shooters.

												KIlling Floor isn't just your average FPS.  Improving your stats, and not to mention, surviving the game takes a lot of patience and even more teamwork.  The replay value is high thanks to Perks (character classes) that take an incredible but worthwhile amount of time to level up, a wide range of weapons to experiment (or toy!) with and different maps.  A good deal of knowledge about the game mechanics is necessary to make it through the extermination runs, but that's where friends come in handy.  When playing with a team you can trust, then win or lose, the experience is just amazing!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Simply put, if you enjoy First Person Shooters, Survival Games, Co-op, or horror, you will LOVE Killing Floor.This game sports a variety of weapons, each designed for a "Class". When you start a match, you can choose a Perk, making you suited for a role (ex. Medic, Support Specialist, and Commando), you can change the perk at any time though, and you level up the perks gradually, helping you face harder difficulties (which you can select at any time). As a team, or alone, you face waves of genetically modified clones, that each have unique traits (for example, one type can cloak, another can walk on walls and leap far distances). At the end wave, you fight a "Boss" of sorts, that has a rocket launcher on its shoulder, and a chaingun for an arm. Yeah, it can be as hard as it sounds. That's how a standard match goes, but as of late, objective based maps have also been introduced, and the Developers make special events for holidays and seasons, and also update things just for the sake of supporting the game, and adding new stuff. You can also shake things up a bit with mods, which you can easily get on the Steam Workshop. Mods include maps (which can have objectives or special things like acid floors, for instance), weapons, character models, and even unique gamemodes, like one that is directly based on the Aliens franchise. Overall, I would say that it is a very addicting game with extensive support from the developers and the community. It is also fairly cheap, and honestly, it is not much of a risky buy, because it is honestly just so addicting (coming from a FPS lover).

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												First of all I would just say that Killing Floor (KF) is a very good game if you are looking for somehting to do when you are bored or just want to kill some monsters.  Positive GraphicsGameplayMany mapsMultiplayer Negative Class balanceHigh level requirments (level 5 and up)So lets talk about why I think all those things are positive and negative. The graphics are looking good and really fits this type of game without feeling strange and missplaced. When it comes to the gameplay I think that the monsters are balanced and there is always a challenge in trying to win but ofcourse that depends on what difficulty you are playing on(!). There is alot of map and plenty more to be downloaded that have been made by others, you will not get bored easily with all these maps. The multiplayer works really well and does almost always work without any problem, sometimes some friends have trouble joining the server even when there is no problem from our side but hey that does not happen often so no point in complaining to much about it.So why do I think that the class balance is bad? For example the berseker can run around and 1-hit most of the monsters without breaking a sweat while other classes have to shoot like a madman to kil them. But that also depends on where you shoot. Also the bonuses each class get when they reach level 5 is kinda unbalanced. The medic gets a body armor while others gets weapons that are worth more, that is not really nice but still a body armor is atleast something. When you reach level 5 as a medic you have to heal 2.5x the amount you have healed to reach level 5 just to get to level 6 which is a big leap. It takes a while depending on how much you play but I guess that they don't everyone to reach the high levels so fast.

												A really good zombie FPS. The graphics are very good so is the audio. There is a variety of zombies and most of them are a pain in the butt if you don't have a suitible weapon. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Ahhh, Killing Floor, where do I begin?Back during the christmas steam sale of 2013 my friends and I decided to get this game when it went on sale. Back then we just thought, hey it's a multiplayer game, and it looks pretty cool. We never thought we would sink as much time into this game as we have.It used to hang at the initial load up screen for ages, but even then it worth the 2 minutes of black screen to wait to play this game, the gameplay its self is addictive and enjoyable, the leveling system is a bit too high on the grinding curve if you ask me, once you get to level 4 in the different classes it just drags. I am stoked to see what the next game will bring to the table.Also, what is up with the dialogue, specifically with the trader? Why does she say things like;I like the big ones, don't you?The shop is open, boys; come get me!They're all dead! It's time to go shoppin'!Come and get 'em! Lovely big guns!I'll tool you up, just right.4 of the 5 of those dialogues are definitly spoken with a naughty overtone of sorts, i'm not complaining by any means, at this point its a great joke between my friends and I quoting her and laughing. Anyways, you won't regret getting it, and I am looking forward to Killing Floor 2.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												First of all I would just say that Killing Floor (KF) is a very good game if you are looking for somehting to do when you are bored or just want to kill some monsters.  Positive GraphicsGameplayMany mapsMultiplayer Negative Class balanceHigh level requirments (level 5 and up)So lets talk about why I think all those things are positive and negative. The graphics are looking good and really fits this type of game without feeling strange and missplaced. When it comes to the gameplay I think that the monsters are balanced and there is always a challenge in trying to win but ofcourse that depends on what difficulty you are playing on(!). There is alot of map and plenty more to be downloaded that have been made by others, you will not get bored easily with all these maps. The multiplayer works really well and does almost always work without any problem, sometimes some friends have trouble joining the server even when there is no problem from our side but hey that does not happen often so no point in complaining to much about it.So why do I think that the class balance is bad? For example the berseker can run around and 1-hit most of the monsters without breaking a sweat while other classes have to shoot like a madman to kil them. But that also depends on where you shoot. Also the bonuses each class get when they reach level 5 is kinda unbalanced. The medic gets a body armor while others gets weapons that are worth more, that is not really nice but still a body armor is atleast something. When you reach level 5 as a medic you have to heal 2.5x the amount you have healed to reach level 5 just to get to level 6 which is a big leap. It takes a while depending on how much you play but I guess that they don't everyone to reach the high levels so fast.

content:
Posted: January 19
British Metal Zombie Killers  TL;DR Killing Floor is a Fantastic wave based shooter with challenging gameplay , humorous dialogue and a head banging soundtrack. You and 4 teammates will be pit against the bowels of hell as an array of monsters come to tear your nipples off. Using specialized classes with the weapons you purchase you will help each other to survive by strategic placement or running around like lunatics, that have been given to much sugar.Follow us here Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipPros  Fast pacedGreat Co-op experienceRocking SoundtrackEasy for NewcomersCons Lacking a variety in gameplayNo storyLevels do not change any gameplay---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GameplayIn Killing floor choosing a class sets your playstyle for the match, your either going to be running around and keeping you distance or participating in fisticuffs. The game has very little strategy involved other than find a corner and only kill the last zombie when you’re at the merchant. Even though There are numerous types of monsters and weapons, you’ll find yourself buying the same guns every game, the game sadly can become repetitive in its gameplay. Characters While there are no actual characters with a full-fledged story, the dialogue is delightfully British and witty, with funny quips and spammable taunts. There are roughly 100 character skins to choose from , most are just silly military skins but others are refrences like the tf2 pyro. Art/Graphics Killing floor has that gritty film look and it pulls it off so well , with the dark environments and array of characters and monsters. The small maps usually follow a theme and they all give off a feeling of horror.There are many character models to choose form and variants of the monsters, Yet they all seem to fit nicely in the level themes, Even the Christmas ones are very well made.If you like this join us here to get the latest Reviews:Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group : http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipWhat would you like to see for our next review ? Ask in the comment section!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Human Power!  Killing Floor brings a whole new level of awesome to zombie slaying.  Think shotguns are the best?   Want to be a team player and heal your comrades?  Perhaps you prefer to chop heads left and right?  Or do you simply love to make it rain dosh everywhere you go?  Killing floor has it all, with endless waves of horrifying foes, a wide variety of maps, weapons, and classes, and a healthy competition between your teammates that will have you striving to not only survive, but shine on the scoreboard.  Tripwire even provides periodic updates and holiday events with special achievements and Zed models to keep things fresh.  Cooperate to survive, or style on your teammates by taking on the horde solo.  The Zombie Apocalypse is now!

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												This game... This mind blowing, goretastic Flesh addict slaying game... This is tied with COD WAW Zombies for the whole "Survival" feel.This review will be separated into 3 categories.Graphics: 7.65/10  Although not as pretty as some would expect, the graphics feel right for the theme and are fairly good for the timeframe it was released.Sound: 8/10 The soundtrack is eerie to say the least and although I prefer to have heavy metal playing as I stupidly chainsaw fleshpounds, I still love it.Gameplay: 9.5/10 The shineing feature, The coup' de grace. The single most fun part. From slow-motion headshots, to knifeing a horde, to even Deryl'ing the stalkers it is fun as hell. Final verdict: 9.0/10 Although I admit to being biased due to how much I love this game, I just see it as being good.Good enough to make me give it a serious review. Which means I just have to do this.NotExtinction/10 - Treyarch

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												(Edit now includes : decent grammatic improvements, less bias, less bloat bile, totally different review.)Killing Floor 1 was one of my early steam games, so I had to do it a bit of respectful justice and give it a cleaner review.There's a lot to be said about this game, so get your reading glasses on, and prepare yourself for the hate you'll dish out to me later for the waste of time. The Good Holy hell this was an addictive game for me, it ran beautifully even on cheap flimsy laptops that were nowhere near up to par for gaming, yet you could run it on ultra on good pcs' and end up loving it to pieces that way as well.The Classes were unique right down to the core, spare Combat Medic and Demolition for obvious reasons, their bonuses made you feel like each class had a whole different set of playstyles as well as strengths/weaknesses to them, along with the fact they had a heartwarming discount to their own class-based weapons.The maps were extremely varied, from small london towns, to giant bleak and nuclear fallout-esque forests. There was no ground that wasn't contaminated by Horzine's horrible creations. The Bad The enemies for the most part are somewhat generic, and feel a bit "Clonelike" in design, and I'm not saying that because they're literally clones. The only enemies that truly stood out to me in both design and abilities in the field are : the Fleshpound, The Scrake, and the dreaded Patriarch.The Fleshpound being the least original, in my eyes atleast, because he'll eventually enrage at either not seeing you for so long, or for seeing you for so long, I forget exactly how he was Kited in this game. (If you're unsure what I mean about kiting, or even care to want to know, please don't ask, just look at a guide for Killing Floor and you'll find it easily.)The scrake being the middle point, not only is he big, bulky and terrifyingly quick for someone his size, but he also has a unique damage enragement system, where he will only become enraged at around 50% hp, this meant for team co-ordination not to hit him until the trash was cleaned up.and the horrifying Patriarch, I will have to leave him out mostly since this is already a huge rambling mess, but this was the creator of the Horzine's horrible mistake creations, and he decided to test his experiments on himself as well, and mounted a gattling gun onto his left arm, as well as an RPG for a massive munitions system.The only other bad thing, was no character was really unique to themselves, they either felt the same as the next guy, had the same voice all around, or just never really felt like they were worth going out of the way to buy/earn. The Ugly One of my issues with Killing Floor, that may be up to the community to debate over, was the last year of Tripwire supporting this game, was mostly microtransactions that gave very unattractive weapons, or characters with unusually bad gimmicks, such as leaving a fake trail of dosh around whenever you walk. I'm not usually up for microtransaction hate since it's very petty to hate an optional piece of content, but I will admit they dicked over the community from the last year of KF and onward, ignoring the complaints and even banning some people over voicing their disagreements to them, Tripwire is a very hostile company as of late and if you want to buy their dlc or support it then cheers, but just remember that they're not as nice/mean as people think, they're simply looking to protect their investment and make revenue off of it. Overall Impression While I love this game to bits and pieces, there is definitely an elephant in the room that urks me personally, and that's unfriendly customer support and/or community responses.If the company decides to add dlc, you should decide if Your money is worth it not anybody else's, and nobody should be banned over thinking Tripwire's not exactly doing their job right, because agtain in reality they're not exactly saintlike.All in all I still think this game is a 8/10 game, it's good and has a lot of potential for good times, but there can be a good few repetitive issues to it that you may, or may not enjoy.

Events during Halloween and Christmas were always a blast with themed Zeds to kill and timed achievements to earn.

The Bad The enemies for the most part are somewhat generic, and feel a bit "Clonelike" in design, and I'm not saying that because they're literally clones. The only enemies that truly stood out to me in both design and abilities in the field are : the Fleshpound, The Scrake, and the dreaded Patriarch.The Fleshpound being the least original, in my eyes atleast, because he'll eventually enrage at either not seeing you for so long, or for seeing you for so long, I forget exactly how he was Kited in this game. (If you're unsure what I mean about kiting, or even care to want to know, please don't ask, just look at a guide for Killing Floor and you'll find it easily.)The scrake being the middle point, not only is he big, bulky and terrifyingly quick for someone his size, but he also has a unique damage enragement system, where he will only become enraged at around 50% hp, this meant for team co-ordination not to hit him until the trash was cleaned up.and the horrifying Patriarch, I will have to leave him out mostly since this is already a huge rambling mess, but this was the creator of the Horzine's horrible mistake creations, and he decided to test his experiments on himself as well, and mounted a gattling gun onto his left arm, as well as an RPG for a massive munitions system.The only other bad thing, was no character was really unique to themselves, they either felt the same as the next guy, had the same voice all around, or just never really felt like they were worth going out of the way to buy/earn. The Ugly One of my issues with Killing Floor, that may be up to the community to debate over, was the last year of Tripwire supporting this game, was mostly microtransactions that gave very unattractive weapons, or characters with unusually bad gimmicks, such as leaving a fake trail of dosh around whenever you walk. I'm not usually up for microtransaction hate since it's very petty to hate an optional piece of content, but I will admit they dicked over the community from the last year of KF and onward, ignoring the complaints and even banning some people over voicing their disagreements to them, Tripwire is a very hostile company as of late and if you want to buy their dlc or support it then cheers, but just remember that they're not as nice/mean as people think, they're simply looking to protect their investment and make revenue off of it. Overall Impression While I love this game to bits and pieces, there is definitely an elephant in the room that urks me personally, and that's unfriendly customer support and/or community responses.If the company decides to add dlc, you should decide if Your money is worth it not anybody else's, and nobody should be banned over thinking Tripwire's not exactly doing their job right, because agtain in reality they're not exactly saintlike.All in all I still think this game is a 8/10 game, it's good and has a lot of potential for good times, but there can be a good few repetitive issues to it that you may, or may not enjoy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This is a surprisingly addictive coop, fps, wave-based, zombie survival.Unlike most games Killing Floor simply acknowledges that it is a game. There are multiple types of zombies with their own unique abilities, but not anything special. The game has a good variety of guns and maps, and a perk-based leveling up tree. The amount of achievements is off the wall. With over 250 of them, it's very hard to get bored of this game.Now, the only down side to all of these happy notes. DLC. $8 a pop for nothing but a retextures. $8 for a 4-pack of player models, that do nothing but change the way you look. $8 for a 4-pack of golden weapons that are the same as their in-game equivalents. The only thing that may be col is the community weapons pack, but even for a crossbow that shoots rotary saws... Not worth $8.BUT, that's not an in-game problem, SO BUY KILLING FLOOR NOW!

content:
Posted: January 6, 2011
												Killing Floor suffers from lack of polish, but does resemble a fairly decent coop survival shooter with subtle RPG elements. The game fundamentals are solid even with the lack of continuity by chasing down a trader for gun and ammo purchases between hordes of zombies. For casual players, the RPG elements are much too serious a grind to reach maximum level. The developers continue to put time and effort into keeping the game popular and fun with sales events and new DLC. It's not all that fun to play by yourself, but certainly plenty of entertainment for you and your mates together.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												Spectacular Cooperative Shooter Zombie game! Its filled with tons of exciting new contents every Summer, Halloween and Christmas! Perks are classes and there are only 6 Player classes mean you can easily adjust your playing style if its not working. Slashing your way with a melee weapon as a Berserker, burning the Specimens as a Firebug, you want to blow some explosives? sure you can be a Demolition! You want to do some headshots, pistols or sniping? Be a Sharpshooter! You can mow them down using a Shotgun or Wield the door to trap your teammates as a Support Specialist! Tired of not seeing Stalkers, want to see how much of any specimens have health bar left? lead your comrades to victorious? be a Commando! Lastly, are you in a pain that your teammates is always dying in the middle of the fight and you really want to help them and heal them? be a Field Medic! There are lots of fire arms in this game regarding DLC's weapons, tag along with your friends to battle in the open field map, fending off against the specimens horde until the Patriarch appeared in the last hour...Rated: 9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Alright, even though this game was made in '09, has graphics that would make make a grandmother have a stroke, AI that, in comparison to other games that were released in the same time frame, were clunky and irrational most of the time. Also included is a server browser system that has been known to drive people to insanity.Few games have given me more enjoyment than Killing Floor.The game is very simplistic in its objective: See zombie, shoot zombie, get paid, buy bigger guns, repeat. Even though this may seem boring while you sit there, in your "gaming chair", waiting for your next game of Dota 2 to load, it really isn't. There is nothing more enjoyable and suspenceful than playing with a group of 5 friends (the game allows 6 people in standard servers), everyone dying but you on wave 10 on suicidal, out of ammo against 2 fleshpunds and about 30 other Zeds.The gameplay is very enjoyable, especially on higher difficulties, like suicidal or HoE (Hell on Earth), where teamwork is absolutely essential for survival for all 10 waves. There are 7 perks, each has its own ablilities (like the Berzerker, which does bonus melee damage) and uses for helping your squad survive the onslaught of horrific freaks you're up against. The maps are varied and requie you to shose your perks accordingly, depending on if its a day or night map, or open space or tight corridors. The goal of Killing Floor is to survie all 10 waves to get to wave 11, which is the main freak leader himself: the Patriarch. If you kill him (no mercy allowed), your squad survives. If all of you die in the course of 1 round, you lose. At the end of each round, any dead players respawn, but only if there are still surviving players.Tripwire has done a very good job of keeping players in the game durring its 5 years of release. They have done special events, such as The Twisted Christmas Event, or Hillbilly Horror (Halloween). Also, a steady drip of new maps, characters, and    guns have fallen into the hands of eagerly awaiting fans, most of which are given freely, or in-game achievement unlocks. Even though there are several packs of guns only available through paid DLC, they do not affect game ballance in the least, but only serve to vary gameplay and team tactics. Also included is the complete is a very extensive set of  od tools, allowing useres to create vurtually anything they want with the game; now that Killing Floor has Workshop, a hwole new relm of content has been opend to players.Over all, this game has kept me satified for over a year, as well as Tripwire gaining my respect for thier devotion to their playerbase. Alright Tripwire, time to bring Killing Floor 2 to the eagerly awating masses.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Are you thinking about getting yourself Killing Floor? If so, I have just three questions for you: Do you like FPS games? Do you like co-op based multiplayer games? Do you have couple of friends to play with? If you have answered yes three times, there is nothing else you need to know. Killing Floor is going to provide you and your friends with lots of fun. There you are with bunch of friends challenging hordes of mutants knowing you have no chance to survive on your own. Working together is the only way through and you guys are gonna enjoy it because there is plenty of weapons to choose from. When you are bored of shotguns and machine guns, you can try roasting yourself a mutant burger with flamethrower or cutting a slice of mutant bacon with brand new katana. But nothing beats boredom as well as good old grenade launcher.The ways to dispose of mutants are numerous but the same could be said about the ways you can die. You can either drown in acid vomit from huge Bloats, get butchered by Gorefasts, humanlike mutants with blades instead of hands, devoured alive by insectlike Crawlers or just get drilled down by almost unkillable Fleshpounds. If you hold up long enough and make it to the end of the stage, you will face Patriarch, nasty piece of mutant-ish weaponry who will do anything to butcher the ones who killed his babies.Killing Floor is definitely good game which provides great fun for the buck, considering how cheaply you can get the base game. There is only one problem, the DLC policy, not too uncommon in these days (Hi Bethesda) when getting half of the new DLCs will cost you more than GotY edition, which is kind of unfair to people who already own some.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Killing Floor is an example of multiplayer survival done right. Sure, there's single player but that's honestly as boring as the game gets. Multiplayer is where you should head with this game, even if you're playing with strangers, if they're competant and follow a very, very basic strategy, you can still have fun. The game is difficult, it takes a lot of practice on each difficulty before you can step up to the next one, along with the need to constantly boost your perks. The perks are very helpful and actually affect gameplay in terms of damage output, weapon costs, etc. but levelling them up is a grindfest; However if you're having fun then you wont even notice.The gameplay is wavebased, with a brief time-period allocated to buying weapons at the end of each wave. It's a lot more strategic than it first seems, at harder difficulties you need to have an idea of what you're doing before you even start, what weapons to buy, when to buy them. Additionally, if you're playing with friends you generally need to decide right from the beginning who uses what perk to aid the team, who buys specific weapons to deal with specific enemies, and what strategy to follow. The game's difficulty only adds to the tension and atmosphere, that coupled with a satisfying gore system makes it fun.The game is modder friendly so there's countless maps, skins and mods to keep you busy if you're bored of vanilla, just bring d0sh, lads.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Killing Floor is a great zombie survival game which does not have the attributes which some don't like about the zombies from Call of Duty, this zombie survival game has an end to it.The game has multiple difficulties to choose from as well as multiple perks to enhance different play styles.  The perks enhance things such as explosive damage, headshot damage multiplier, shotgun damage and many other things.  Each perk of course can be levelled up so that the perk offers more enhancements to the specific playstyle, such as the support specialist is a perk that enhances the stats for shotgun users, the perk levels up from weld points which are gained from welding and unwelding doors and of course the other portion of levelling up the perk is gained from distributing damage with shotguns.  Once perks are levelled up to level 5 and 6 bonuses are added alongside the perk such as starting weapons and possibly armor.There are multiple maps to choose form while playing Killing Floor and each game played consists of 10 waves and a final boss wave.  The boss is a zombie called The Patriarch.In this game there are multiple types of zombies instead of just one type which other games tend to stick with, each zombie is a different styled zombie varying in strength and agility.Overall this game has a lot of different aspects to it and is a very enjoyable game which has a lot of replay value in it and I recommend it to any survival horror game enthusiast.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Killing Floor is a game that I pick up every now and then, and always end up wondering, "Why don't I play this more often?" The weapons are very satisfying to use, and every enemy in the game can be a reasonable threat. The final boss is among the most lethal of that I have ever seen (despite the fact that there are ways of easily beating him), as he is: faster than you, has an instant-kill rocket launcher attack, a minigun that has a chance of killing you in a burst (about a second), and melee attacks that brutalize you/send you flying away. This game is especially fun with friends, and the 7 (pretty sure it's 7) classes are all useful in some respect. I highly recommend picking up this game at sometime, especially if it goes on sale.

												This game is amazing. The graphics aren't that bad, it runs really smoothly, and tons of fun. You can literally play this game for hours on end. The monsters are creepy and disgusting as heck and the weapons are all so badass. It also has so many different players, so you can always find a server that has people on it. And I love the thrill of the game; it just scares the @#$% out of me when I see a Gorefast or Scrake charging at me. There is literally so much good stuff you can say about this game. I give it 10/10! It is worth the dosh (in-game reference :P)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Killing Floor is an FPS zombie Shooter.  It's generally a multiplayer game but the game let's you play solo by setting up a server where no other players can join, so effectively you get single player OR you can play with friends coop.  The game starts with you facing down the first wave of zombies.  During this wave, you must slowly find your way to the shop keeper so you can upgrade your gear (weapons, items, etc).  The shop keeper is somewhere on the map and there's an arrow in yur HUD pointing in the direction of the next shop.  If you clear a wave then a red trail appears showing you exactly where the shop is.  You can customize for more waves by selecting a longer game.  Each wave is kept track of in your HUD, with zombie and wave count.There are items like guns and ammo available for pick up around the map.  The weapons available at the shop aren't bad but generally, if you've opted for the DLC then you have a bigger choice of weapons to use.  Weapons basically have a cumbersome/weight factor so you can't carry everything you want for each wave of zombies.  There are varrying zombies that do several things so depending on what you're facing might depend on what loadout you choose. When you have zombies firing missile launchers in your direction, you may opt for the body armor.The graphics aren't bad for an old game... but it is an old game so you're dealing with an old graphics engine no matter how much DLC you add to your initial game.  There's several unique zombies and creatures that are pretty creative in their gore factor. Headshots have that slow motion action feel to them adding to the eye candy effect a bit.  There is quite a following of the game and there's even new DLC every so often that include maps and unique character sets with tons of achievements to farm for.  There's plenty of maps and the better you know the map, the better you play.  Incidentally, there's no mini-map so you REALLY have to know the map for longer survival and shop locations.  My only real problem with the game is that you can't run.  If you're used to playing COD or some other FPS where you can just take up a sprint... not here.  The game will let you slow down to a walk though.  I'm assuming for better aim as you're moving and firing at the same time.  I'm a fan of Tripwire games so this is right in there as a classic fave.  It's an old game but I'd still recommend it ON SALE... with the DLC on sale.  You can get multiple DLC packages and the game itself super cheap when there's a sale.  Looking forward to Killing Floor 2 for sure.

												I have logged so many hours into this game it is ridiculous. Every person I have recommended this game likes it.Killing Floor is sorta like a horde game where you and your teammates kill waves of dead specimens getting money. At the end of each wave a shop opens and you get to purchase weapons, stock on ammo grenades kevlar for the next round.It's not like left 4 dead where you follow a trail to get from point A to B, but in Killing Floor the whole map is opened to explore.Pros: hilarious English voice accents, many weapons which feel balanced and realistic with recoil, a nice class/perk leveling up system, great many various maps, slow motion kills(although some people dont like it), and an overall satisfaction to recking all the specimens down and blowing them limbs offCons: dated graphics, unlike left 4 dead where u have to get to the chopper, there is no real objective other than survive the final wave,no character differentiation what so ever, all are clones with same voice acting which sucks cuz you get to pick a character and class to play as,some achievements are damn near impossible to get since the game can get really hard at suicidal and hell on earth difficulties.I highly recommend this game. The gaming community is still much alive so you should be able to find plenty of servers to join the fun.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2011
												Killing Floor suffers from lack of polish, but does resemble a fairly decent coop survival shooter with subtle RPG elements. The game fundamentals are solid even with the lack of continuity by chasing down a trader for gun and ammo purchases between hordes of zombies. For casual players, the RPG elements are much too serious a grind to reach maximum level. The developers continue to put time and effort into keeping the game popular and fun with sales events and new DLC. It's not all that fun to play by yourself, but certainly plenty of entertainment for you and your mates together.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Killing Floor is probably one of the best co-op FPS's of all time. While I'm not a huge fan of leveling systems in FPS games, it works here because you don't have to fight against people who've already unlocked everything (and who could likely wipe the floor with you). But don't think the game is easy just because of that. It's not uncommon for even an experienced team to get overwhelmed in later rounds.The game's buying-between-rounds system lets you really change how you play and adapt to the skill level of your teammates. If you're playing with a lot of good people, you could pick up less-effective weapons and just have fun. If your team is struggling, you can go for your bread-and-butter weapons and mop up. You can switch roles between rounds as well, so maybe you're not helping out so much as a Firebug and your team is taking too much damage. You could switch to medic and see a huge turnaround in your team's performance.The aiming is as accurate as you are, and that's a seriously refereshing reward. No artificial inaccuracy or auto-aiming here. There's also no bullet-drop, so it's really a blend of realism and arcadish fun. You have to balance weapon load out with movement speed. The more you carry, the slower you go. Also, you have to be proficient at switching to the right weapon for the job. If you think you can pick any class and one weapon and just mow down every specimen in the game, think again. A support specialist with the right shotgun can solo a flesh pound with little practice. However, a commando with a bullpup should probably just switch to their knife and run away (like CS, you have to switch to your knife if you want to run).One of the few downsides to the game is that there is a lack of variety in enemies on any given map. You'll see the exact same set of enemies over and over again. If you don't absolutely fall in love with the game mechanics, I suspect this will be the aspect of the game that destroys replayability the fastest. It'd be nice to see a couple different models or skins for the same enemy type (like how the plain zombies in L4D1 & 2 don't all look the same). It'd also be nice to see a new enemy type (something I don't think we've ever seen from TripWire Interactive).However, you do get variety in the form of seasonal events which TWI is very good about putting on every year. Often they'll release new content (new map, new character, new weapons, balance tweaks, etc.), and they also reskin all enemies for these events. The graphics may be starting to show their age, but the gameplay is still unique and fun. It's a game that may not have the strongest foundation when it was released, but its content, stability, and overall quality has grown over the years. It's still played by many and easy to pick up at a great price during a steam sale.If you like challenging FPSs and enjoy co-op, definitely give this game a try.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												KIlling Floor isn't just your average FPS.  Improving your stats, and not to mention, surviving the game takes a lot of patience and even more teamwork.  The replay value is high thanks to Perks (character classes) that take an incredible but worthwhile amount of time to level up, a wide range of weapons to experiment (or toy!) with and different maps.  A good deal of knowledge about the game mechanics is necessary to make it through the extermination runs, but that's where friends come in handy.  When playing with a team you can trust, then win or lose, the experience is just amazing!

content:
Posted: January 19
British Metal Zombie Killers  TL;DR Killing Floor is a Fantastic wave based shooter with challenging gameplay , humorous dialogue and a head banging soundtrack. You and 4 teammates will be pit against the bowels of hell as an array of monsters come to tear your nipples off. Using specialized classes with the weapons you purchase you will help each other to survive by strategic placement or running around like lunatics, that have been given to much sugar.Follow us here Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipPros  Fast pacedGreat Co-op experienceRocking SoundtrackEasy for NewcomersCons Lacking a variety in gameplayNo storyLevels do not change any gameplay---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GameplayIn Killing floor choosing a class sets your playstyle for the match, your either going to be running around and keeping you distance or participating in fisticuffs. The game has very little strategy involved other than find a corner and only kill the last zombie when you’re at the merchant. Even though There are numerous types of monsters and weapons, you’ll find yourself buying the same guns every game, the game sadly can become repetitive in its gameplay. Characters While there are no actual characters with a full-fledged story, the dialogue is delightfully British and witty, with funny quips and spammable taunts. There are roughly 100 character skins to choose from , most are just silly military skins but others are refrences like the tf2 pyro. Art/Graphics Killing floor has that gritty film look and it pulls it off so well , with the dark environments and array of characters and monsters. The small maps usually follow a theme and they all give off a feeling of horror.There are many character models to choose form and variants of the monsters, Yet they all seem to fit nicely in the level themes, Even the Christmas ones are very well made.If you like this join us here to get the latest Reviews:Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group : http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipWhat would you like to see for our next review ? Ask in the comment section!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2010
												Killing Floor is an FPS Zombie Killing Game that gives you 6 different perks to choose from. Once you have chosen a perk, you can switch anytime in between waves of the current game or while in the lobby. The game is kind of like Horde from Gears of War or Firefight from Halo 3: ODST in being that you fight against waves of enemies and then against a boss at the end of the last wave. You get to level up each perk to a maximum of 6 levels and with each level, you get really cool benefits. At the end of each wave, you can buy weapons/armor/grenades from this shop that opens up at random locations throughout the map. There's only a certain amount of time to shop and the higher the difficulty, the less time..this means that if you're far away from the shop before it opens...you're screwed! Overall, this is a really fun game, it has excellent gameplay and gore, and it's worth the buy!

												One of my favorite games next to Payday. If you're looking for a co-op survival wave thing similar to CoD zombies then this is the game for you, except the fact that this is probably better than what any CoD zombie game has to offer you. The people are pretty friendly and nice, they'll give you a boost when they can by sparing you some dosh if you come in late. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Alright, even though this game was made in '09, has graphics that would make make a grandmother have a stroke, AI that, in comparison to other games that were released in the same time frame, were clunky and irrational most of the time. Also included is a server browser system that has been known to drive people to insanity.Few games have given me more enjoyment than Killing Floor.The game is very simplistic in its objective: See zombie, shoot zombie, get paid, buy bigger guns, repeat. Even though this may seem boring while you sit there, in your "gaming chair", waiting for your next game of Dota 2 to load, it really isn't. There is nothing more enjoyable and suspenceful than playing with a group of 5 friends (the game allows 6 people in standard servers), everyone dying but you on wave 10 on suicidal, out of ammo against 2 fleshpunds and about 30 other Zeds.The gameplay is very enjoyable, especially on higher difficulties, like suicidal or HoE (Hell on Earth), where teamwork is absolutely essential for survival for all 10 waves. There are 7 perks, each has its own ablilities (like the Berzerker, which does bonus melee damage) and uses for helping your squad survive the onslaught of horrific freaks you're up against. The maps are varied and requie you to shose your perks accordingly, depending on if its a day or night map, or open space or tight corridors. The goal of Killing Floor is to survie all 10 waves to get to wave 11, which is the main freak leader himself: the Patriarch. If you kill him (no mercy allowed), your squad survives. If all of you die in the course of 1 round, you lose. At the end of each round, any dead players respawn, but only if there are still surviving players.Tripwire has done a very good job of keeping players in the game durring its 5 years of release. They have done special events, such as The Twisted Christmas Event, or Hillbilly Horror (Halloween). Also, a steady drip of new maps, characters, and    guns have fallen into the hands of eagerly awaiting fans, most of which are given freely, or in-game achievement unlocks. Even though there are several packs of guns only available through paid DLC, they do not affect game ballance in the least, but only serve to vary gameplay and team tactics. Also included is the complete is a very extensive set of  od tools, allowing useres to create vurtually anything they want with the game; now that Killing Floor has Workshop, a hwole new relm of content has been opend to players.Over all, this game has kept me satified for over a year, as well as Tripwire gaining my respect for thier devotion to their playerbase. Alright Tripwire, time to bring Killing Floor 2 to the eagerly awating masses.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												An instant zombie classic. This game brought me together with many friends and introduced me to many other awesome gamers who like to kill zombies. Games can range from short - long, lasting 4 waves - 10 waves, with a Patriarch boss getting his own wave at the end. Similar to L4D, except gameplay is wave based not objective based. However there is an objective play mode with a few maps that are fun as well. From your basic zombie (referred to as ZEDs in this game) to the intimidating Fleshpound and Scrake, there are many different special zombie types who will all try to eat you in different ways.There are 7 perk types to play as, from the melee Berserker, to the Medic, to the Sharpshooter, there is likely a class you will really enjoy playing.Play solo or with a group up to 6, and on custom servers upwards of 30 players on one server.Many players have created custom maps or objective modes that are unique and fun to play, aside from the 30~ish regular maps, if you like killing zombies, this game can get addicting. There are 5 difficulty levels, and starting out you really should play on 1/5 - Beginner, because as you level your perks (which level to 6 ((higher on custom servers))) you will become stronger with those weapon types and gain necessary benefits to damage and survival that you need to have for higher difficulties.After 700~ hours, I've completed all but a handful of maps on 4/5 diff - Suicidal. It's extremely challenging and 5/5 diff is even more ridiculous. If you're good at FPS you will get the hang of it, but like any game, this one in particular takes time and practice.A great game to play with friends as well, the more perk types your team can cover the better chances you have of surviving, although it is possible to solo most difficulties with any perk, some are more challenging than others. Each perk has a role that they perform and zombies they should focus on taking out, teamwork is key and if you are a lone wolf you can stick with solo.Still fun after years of playing it. Up there with L4D.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Killing Floor is my new favorite horde-based game, that's what you do KF, mow down legions of zombies with your team(under most circumstances). If that concept appeals to you then the rest should even more, there are a variety of enemies to keep you aware from the simple clot to the irritating Sirens as well as the Flesh Pounds. The multiple classes(which are levelable by the way) give you many different approaches to combat zombies, I find the demolition class to be particularily up to my speed. Explosives+zombies= a fun combination. The adjustable difficulty levels add a lot to Killing Floor's replay value, even if you've just started, the beginning difficulty proved entertaining and easygoing as I learned the basic ins and outs of the game.I recommend this game for anyone who's seeking a fun co-op experience and likes killing zombies.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Killing Floor is quite possibly the best zombie survival/horror game I have played. It's always a great game to bust out at a LAN party and provides endless hours of enjoyment for everyone involved! It has something that Left4Dead never did: a leveling system! That means there is always something to strive for and it keeps you coming back for more. The class system makes the game very interesting but more than anything it is important to note that this game is HARD! for the longest time my friends and I couldn't get past Beginner difficulty! All in all this game gets a five star review for me. there's not much in the way of a story which is fine because nobody expected it to be more than a fun multiplayer survival horror game, and oh does it provide on that level.

												Wave based zombie (I know it's speice men..) killing done RIGHT! It's amazing fun and refreshing with a fresh class based system, leveling up each class specifically to use different weapons with more effiency. 												I just picked this game up on sale for $5, and let me just say that it's awesome! Killing Floor boasts LOADS of maps, 7 different classes/perks each with their own special stats and advantages, ZEDtime (slow mo that makes kills look especially sweet, even in multiplayer), lots of achievements, and no shortage of assorted weapons from fire axes, assault rifles, shotguns, SMGs, to flamethrowers and rocket launchers. If you're a fan of co-op and survival horror games, then this game is an absolute must. Haven't been able to stop playing in my free time thus far. And be warned: it's challenging for even the best players.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2013
												Starting out as a mod for Unreal Tournament it expanded into it's own game. And we were lucky that happened. Upon starting the game and getting right to the Zed killing your character is this cute looking military guy called Corporal Lewis. Watching him and the other characters "run" is one of the more amusing animations in this game. They kind of waddle. While the graphics are sorely dated at this point, it's the gameplay that keeps people coming back. Up to six squad members battle it out to kill the most Zeds to earn money to upgrade weapons. But you have to work as a team in order to make it to the boss round and win. There are a large variety of Zeds. From the small but quick Crawlers to the large and slow Bloats (think Boomer from Left 4 Dead). They all attack differently and you have to be prepared for it or you could end up dead lickity split. There are two Zeds however that stand out. The Fleshpound (think the Tank) and the Scrake (not like the Charger but kind of close). These two are extremely powerful and take certain perks (loadouts) to kill. Then there is the boss, the Patriarch. It takes all your ammo and your squads ammo to really take him down which makes it very satisfying when you do. Another great addition to this game were holiday events the devs would release. So in the summer they had a "Summer Sideshow" event a couple of times where you got new achievements and maps to unlock and circus Zeds to fight. Then there were Halloween events with their own set of achievements and maps and Halloween Zeds and lastly Christmas events.Fun gameplay, has awesome holiday events that transform the enemies and locales to fit either the 4th of July, Halloween or Christmas. Plus has the villain who needs a hug the most.
